1.text: Boast not for to morrow, for thou knowest not what the day to come may bring forth.

2.text: Let another praise thee, and not thy own mouth: a stranger, and not thy own lips.

3.text: A stone is heavy, and sand weighty: but the anger of a fool is heavier than them both.

4.text: Anger hath no mercy, nor fury when it breaketh forth: and who can bear the violence of one provoked?

5.text: Open rebuke is better than hidden love.

6.text: Better are the wounds of a friend, than the deceitful kisses of an enemy.

7.text: A soul that is full shall tread upon the honeycomb : and a soul that is hungry shall take even bitter for sweet.

8.text: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so is a man that leaveth his place.

9.text: Ointment and perfumes rejoice the heart: and the good counsels of a friend are sweet to the soul.

10.text: Thy own friend, and thy father’s friend forsake not: and go not into thy brother’s house in the day of thy affliction. Better is a neighbour that is near, than a brother afar off.

11.text: Study wisdom, my son, and make my heart joyful, that thou mayst give an answer to him that reproacheth.

12.text: The prudent man seeing evil hideth himself: little ones passing on have suffered losses.

13.text: Take away his garment that hath been surety for a stranger: and take from him a pledge for strangers.

14.text: He that blesseth his neighbour with a loud voice, rising in the night, shall be like to him that curseth.

15.text: Roofs dropping through in a cold day, and a contentious woman are alike.

16.text: He that retaineth her, is as he that would hold the wind, and shall call in the oil of his right hand.

17.text: Iron sharpeneth iron, so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.

18.text: He that keepeth the fig tree, shall eat the fruit thereof: and he that is the keeper of his master, shall be glorified.

19.text: As the faces of them that look therein, shine in the water, so the hearts of men are laid open to the wise.

20.text: Hell and destruction are never filled: so the eyes of men are never satisfied.

21.text: As silver is tried in the fining-pot and gold in the furnace: so a man is tried by the mouth of him that praiseth. The heart of the wicked seeketh after evils, but the righteous heart seeketh after knowledge.

22.text: Though thou shouldst bray a fool in the mortar, as when a pestle striketh upon sodden barley, his folly would not be taken from him.

23.text: Be diligent to know the countenance of thy cattle, and consider thy own flocks :

24.text: For thou shalt not always have power: but a crown shall be given to generation and generation.

25.text: The meadows are open, and the green herbs have appeared, and the hay is gathered out of the mountains.

26.text: Lambs are for thy clothing: and kids for the price of the field.

27.text: Let the milk of the goats be enough for thy food, and for the necessities of thy house, and for maintenance for thy handmaids.
